awd_titl_txt: Computational Creativity to Improve Computer Science Education for CS and non-CS Undergraduates
awd_abstract_narration:
Both computational and creative thinking are frequently cited as critical workforce attributes. This project, at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, will build on work previously funded under the TUES program (DUE-1122956 "Integrating Computational and Creative Thinking"). The project team will produce a final suite of validated, high quality Computational Creativity Exercises (CCEs) and an associated computational creativity course. They will also carry out rigorous research to understand the efficacy of the CCEs, how that is affected by collaborative interactions and student learning processes, and the impact CCEs have on enrollment and retention in computer science (CS) and science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) courses. CCEs provide an opportunity to creatively solve problems that require a CS principle without writing program code.  The exercises encourage development of creative competencies and have already been implemented across a set of introductory CS courses that have common core content but are tailored for different student populations based on their declared majors.  In this new project the research team will expand the dissemination and implementation of the CCEs and gain increased understanding of the factors that influence efficacy of the exercises.  In addition to dissemination of the exercises and project outcomes, and a workshop for interested faculty, the project impact will be further broadened because the resulting Computational Creativity Course can be delivered via distance education.  In addition, the project team will update and enhance K-12 versions of the exercises that have been deployed on Google's Exploring Computational Thinking site.  

The foundation of this project is that both computational thinking and creative thinking are viewed as cognitive tools.  The CCEs are anchored in instructional design principles such as problem-based learning, written analysis, and reflection.  The CCEs correspond to the learning principles of the Unified Learning Model, a learning theory derived from research in cognitive neuroscience, cognitive science, and psychology.  The main contribution of this project will be to study what implementation conditions impact exercise effectiveness, how student characteristics impact exercise effectiveness, and why exercises produce an effect on learning.  There is an extensive evaluation plan that utilizes many types of data including assessments embedded within the exercises, surveys and focus groups, course and exercise grades, and metadata that will provide measures of engagement with specific elements of course material. In addition to project results and artifacts, the substantial database of data and metadata collected will also be made available to other researchers.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The project generated two general types of outcomes: (1) the Computational Creativity Exercises (CCEs) and the associated instructional pedagogy that have been created, documented, disseminated and made available, as well as the design rationales behind such exercises to allow for others to adopt and adapt such exercises in their instruction, (2) the research studies into computer science education for majors and non-majors, with findings on self-regulation, implicit mindset, and other factors impacting student learning and performance, as well as the survey instruments and knowledge tests developed to collect data and assess learners, and the data collected.  In addition, students, instructors, practitioners, and researchers have been impacted by the project as a student practicing the CCEs in their class, or an instructor learning the importance of integrating computational thinking and creative thinking in their classroom, or others using our survey instruments, knowledge tests, and CCEs in their research, practice, and instruction, or learning about our findings through our publications.  These CCEs are intended to help students see the “big picture” of computing and problem solving in computing disciplines by abstracting computational thinking from programming tasks. 

Broader Impacts.  Computational creativity has the potential impact to significantly change the way subject matters can be effectively taught because of three main reasons. First, the numerous research studies that we have carried out show the impact of CCEs on student learning and improvement. There are indications that CCEs contribute to learning in CS classes regardless of students’ individual motivation related to the class, an important feature of any instructional method. The effect sizes for CCEs have been similar to or higher than the effect sizes found in recent meta-analyses of widely recommended evidenced-based instructional methods in CS and other domains, including active learning, cooperative learning, problem-based learning, and the use of clickers.  Second, the approach, as highlighted in a Teaching Paper that the project has published on EngageCSEdu, to adopting and developing such an exercise is not limited to the researchers of this project, but in general can be practiced by instructors.  Third, the CCEs have been developed in different versions to meet K-16 needs, some of which have been adopted for K-12 by Google’s Exploring Computational Thinking and by NCWIT’s EngageCSEdu (with one of the CCEs receiving the Honorable Mention in 2018 NCWIT Engagement Excellence Awards), and have been incorporated at other institutions.

Intellectual Merits.  The project investigated the relationships among a variety of motivation and self-regulated learning constructs and markers of achievement and retention in CS courses. In most cases, the project found similar relationships to those that had been found in other research. But here are several key novel findings that have enriched the literature in CS education research in particular and STEM education research in general:

 

  • Higher approach goals, perceived instrumentality, and positive affect tend to be associated with higher learning and achievement, while higher avoidance goals and negative affect tend to be associated with lower learning and achievement. 
  • Initial course motivation and its relationship with achievement in introductory CS is different for different groups of students. This finding highlights the importance of replicating motivation research in a variety of contexts.
  • Higher CS-specific career aspirations and knowledge of computing careers at the start of the semester was predictive of students’ continued enrollment in CS courses for three subsequent semesters. This suggests that the previously described focus on career prospects might be a beneficial motivator when it comes to their progression through academic coursework.
  • Students view the more adaptive approach goals as more important than maladaptive avoidance goals, but by the end of the semester, the difference between the two classes of goals had shrunk. There is also evidence that student goals change while they are taking courses, and those changes are part of a larger dynamic system that includes motivation and emotion, self-regulated learning, and the classroom environment. 
  • Students' perceptions of how the course connects to the attainment of future outcomes and computing-related career aspirations shift during the course of a semester, and these changes are related.  In particular, non-CS majors come to believe more strongly that the primary connection between the course and their future was the grade they would earn, and they see less of a connection between course content and their future, and their computing-related career aspirations also decrease during the semester. 
  • There are shifts in an aspect of one's domain-general beliefs: implicit theories of intelligence, popularly known as "mindsets". Undergraduate CS students trend towards an entity-oriented belief system across time. The project detected increasing entity beliefs and decreasing incremental beliefs across single semesters for CS students enrolled in introductory and upper-level courses, with most of this change occurring during the first half of the semester. 


 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2022
Modified by: Leen-Kiat Soh
por.por_txt_cntn:
The project generated two general types of outcomes: (1) the Computational Creativity Exercises (CCEs) and the associated instructional pedagogy that have been created, documented, disseminated and made available, as well as the design rationales behind such exercises to allow for others to adopt and adapt such exercises in their instruction, (2) the research studies into computer science education for majors and non-majors, with findings on self-regulation, implicit mindset, and other factors impacting student learning and performance, as well as the survey instruments and knowledge tests developed to collect data and assess learners, and the data collected.  In addition, students, instructors, practitioners, and researchers have been impacted by the project as a student practicing the CCEs in their class, or an instructor learning the importance of integrating computational thinking and creative thinking in their classroom, or others using our survey instruments, knowledge tests, and CCEs in their research, practice, and instruction, or learning about our findings through our publications.  These CCEs are intended to help students see the "big picture" of computing and problem solving in computing disciplines by abstracting computational thinking from programming tasks. 

Broader Impacts.  Computational creativity has the potential impact to significantly change the way subject matters can be effectively taught because of three main reasons. First, the numerous research studies that we have carried out show the impact of CCEs on student learning and improvement. There are indications that CCEs contribute to learning in CS classes regardless of students’ individual motivation related to the class, an important feature of any instructional method. The effect sizes for CCEs have been similar to or higher than the effect sizes found in recent meta-analyses of widely recommended evidenced-based instructional methods in CS and other domains, including active learning, cooperative learning, problem-based learning, and the use of clickers.  Second, the approach, as highlighted in a Teaching Paper that the project has published on EngageCSEdu, to adopting and developing such an exercise is not limited to the researchers of this project, but in general can be practiced by instructors.  Third, the CCEs have been developed in different versions to meet K-16 needs, some of which have been adopted for K-12 by Google’s Exploring Computational Thinking and by NCWIT’s EngageCSEdu (with one of the CCEs receiving the Honorable Mention in 2018 NCWIT Engagement Excellence Awards), and have been incorporated at other institutions.

Intellectual Merits.  The project investigated the relationships among a variety of motivation and self-regulated learning constructs and markers of achievement and retention in CS courses. In most cases, the project found similar relationships to those that had been found in other research. But here are several key novel findings that have enriched the literature in CS education research in particular and STEM education research in general:

 

Higher approach goals, perceived instrumentality, and positive affect tend to be associated with higher learning and achievement, while higher avoidance goals and negative affect tend to be associated with lower learning and achievement. 
Initial course motivation and its relationship with achievement in introductory CS is different for different groups of students. This finding highlights the importance of replicating motivation research in a variety of contexts.
Higher CS-specific career aspirations and knowledge of computing careers at the start of the semester was predictive of students’ continued enrollment in CS courses for three subsequent semesters. This suggests that the previously described focus on career prospects might be a beneficial motivator when it comes to their progression through academic coursework.
Students view the more adaptive approach goals as more important than maladaptive avoidance goals, but by the end of the semester, the difference between the two classes of goals had shrunk. There is also evidence that student goals change while they are taking courses, and those changes are part of a larger dynamic system that includes motivation and emotion, self-regulated learning, and the classroom environment. 
Students' perceptions of how the course connects to the attainment of future outcomes and computing-related career aspirations shift during the course of a semester, and these changes are related.  In particular, non-CS majors come to believe more strongly that the primary connection between the course and their future was the grade they would earn, and they see less of a connection between course content and their future, and their computing-related career aspirations also decrease during the semester. 
There are shifts in an aspect of one's domain-general beliefs: implicit theories of intelligence, popularly known as "mindsets". Undergraduate CS students trend towards an entity-oriented belief system across time. The project detected increasing entity beliefs and decreasing incremental beliefs across single semesters for CS students enrolled in introductory and upper-level courses, with most of this change occurring during the first half of the semester.
